Sentencas: The effects of intermediate nickel layer on seal strength and chemical compatibility of seal glass and interconnect materials for solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs) were investigated.
Titulo: Effect of intermediate nickel layer on seal strength and chemical compatibility of glass and ferritic stainless steel in oxidizing environment for solid oxide fuel cells

Sentencas: Two types of samples (metal/glass/metal sandwiches and glass coated metals) were prepared with the sheet of AISI 430 (nickel plated and uncoated) and slurry of compliant silicate sealing glass (SCN-1).
Titulo: Effect of intermediate nickel layer on seal strength and chemical compatibility of glass and ferritic stainless steel in oxidizing environment for solid oxide fuel cells

Sentencas: The joined and coated samples were heated at 850 degrees C for different time durations (0.5-100 h).
Titulo: Effect of intermediate nickel layer on seal strength and chemical compatibility of glass and ferritic stainless steel in oxidizing environment for solid oxide fuel cells

Sentencas: Tensile and impact tests were performed and SEM micrographs were used to analyze the glass/metal interaction.
Titulo: Effect of intermediate nickel layer on seal strength and chemical compatibility of glass and ferritic stainless steel in oxidizing environment for solid oxide fuel cells

Sentencas: The results indicate that nickel plated AISI 430 shows higher adhesion strength at short durations of heating due to dendrite development at the interface.
Titulo: Effect of intermediate nickel layer on seal strength and chemical compatibility of glass and ferritic stainless steel in oxidizing environment for solid oxide fuel cells

Sentencas: For longer durations, intermediate nickel layer leads to rapid loss of adhesion strength due to extension of unstable austenite zones but prevents the accelerated weakening near the triple-phase boundaries metal/glass/air (TPB) by compensating for absence of protective oxide layer (Cr-Mn oxide).
Titulo: Effect of intermediate nickel layer on seal strength and chemical compatibility of glass and ferritic stainless steel in oxidizing environment for solid oxide fuel cells
